title-group.article-title: Holocene lake-level fluctuations in Lakes Keilambete and Gnotuk, southwestern Victoria, Australia

article-meta.aff: 1Research School of Earth Sciences, The Australian National University, Australia
2Research School of Physics and Engineering, The Australian National University, Australia
3Earth Observatory of Singapore, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore

author-notes.corresp: Daniel Wilkins, Australian Antarctic Division, Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities, 203 Channel Highway, Kingston TAS 7050, Australia. Email: daniel.wilkins@aad.gov.au

abstract.p: Reconstructed Holocene lake-level curves from two saline, hydrologically closed maar crater lakes in southwestern Victoria, Australia, show near synchronous lake-level changes throughout the Holocene. We show that lake levels, reconstructed from sediment particle size and ostracod valve chemistry (δ18O and Sr/Ca) have undergone rapid (<100 yr), large (>10 m) fluctuations throughout the Holocene. Finer sampling resolution shows a more sensitive response to Holocene climate than was previously presented for Lake Keilambete. Both maar crater lakes show a short-lived maximum in Holocene lake levels around 7.2 ka. The period of lake filling leading to peak lake levels matches the phase of most effective precipitation (7.4–7.0 ka) reconstructed from a high-resolution speleothem record from northern Tasmania. Water levels declined in both lakes during the mid Holocene, with a more substantive decline after ~5 ka which coincides with the end of the Southern Hemisphere hypsithermal. Water levels continued to oscillate with a periodicity of around 300–700 years, before reaching a late-Holocene nadir around 1.8 ka (Keilambete) and 1.3 ka (Gnotuk). The trend and periodicity of oscillations in the maar water levels show commonalities to δD in the Dome C ice core, and suggest that temperature may be a significant component in influencing the Precipitation/Evaporation (P/E) ratio in southeastern Australia during the Holocene.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: One of the fundamental goals of palaeoenvironment and palaeoclimate research is to establish pre-anthropogenic data sets with which to compare the impacts of recent (post-industrial revolution) environmental change. In order to accomplish this, robustly dated, high-resolution records are required to gain an understanding of past environmental conditions. This has been achieved in many regions of the world (e.g. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), 2007), however, in southeastern Australia, high-resolution, multiproxy records with good chronological control are lacking. The importance of understanding palaeoenvironmental changes in southeastern Australia is of fundamental importance to future surface and groundwater water resource management (e.g. Kirono et al., 2009, 2012; Yihdego and Webb, 2012) and environmental condition assessments (e.g. Gell et al., 2012).

The Holocene lake-level curve derived from laminated sediments from the Lake Keilambete maar by Bowler (1970, 1981) is a keystone record in the understanding of Holocene climate in southeastern Australia (e.g. see Williams et al., 1998). Other temperate southeastern Australian lakes with high-resolution dating are rare, and often only have a single proxy (e.g. the aeolian quartz record from Blue Lake, NSW (Stanley and De Deckker, 2002)). Lake Keilambete provides a rare continuous record of varying precipitation/evaporation (P/E) throughout the Holocene, and has provided a wealth of multiproxy reconstructions, from lake level (Bowler, 1981; Jones et al., 2001), ostracods (Chivas et al., 1985, 1986, 1993; De Deckker, 1982), and pollen and charcoal (Dodson, 1974a; Mooney, 1997). Bowler’s (1981) smoothed lake-level curve, constructed using grain size data from 40 sediment samples, shows a broad and high plateau in lake levels between ~7.8 and 6.2 ka1 followed by a gradual decline in water level, with low but rapidly oscillating levels from ~ 3.3 to 2.3 ka, followed by a late-Holocene rise and a rapid decline in the post-European period.

Given the arguable importance of Lake Keilambete to our understanding of Holocene climate in southeastern Australia, this paper provides a long overdue, higher-resolution reconstruction of Holocene lake level using independent techniques (sediment texture and ostracod valve chemistry combined with an ostracod transfer function to reconstruct water salinities), dated with two independent methods (Wilkins et al., 2012), and validated by reference to a second maar lake (Lake Gnotuk). Advancements in dating since the time of Bowler’s research has enabled a revision of past bulk 14C dating chronologies for Lake Keilambete and Lake Gnotuk, which shows that Lake Keilambete is affected by a radiocarbon reservoir (Wilkins et al., 2012), whereas Lake Gnotuk is not.

The Lake Keilambete water-level reconstruction presented here more than doubles the temporal resolution of the original reconstruction of Bowler (1981) from one sample every 250 years to one per 100 years for Lake Keilambete. The temporal resolution for Lake Gnotuk is approximately one sample every 150 years, but the lake-level reconstruction still shows excellent agreement with that of Lake Keilambete.

As summarised in Shulmeister (1999), the mid-Holocene decline in lake levels has since been interpreted as reflecting either a (1) reduction in summer (monsoonal) rainfall (e.g. Singh and Luly, 1991), or (2) reduction in winter (westerly) rainfall due to a southerly shift of the subtropical high pressure belt (e.g. Harrison, 1993). Over the last decade, it has become increasingly clear that Southern Hemisphere climate was far more variable than previously thought (e.g. Mayewski et al., 2004; Moros et al., 2009; Moy et al., 2002), yet because of the poor resolution and smoothed nature of the published Keilambete lake-level curve, it is impossible to resolve variability seen elsewhere. Two recently published palaeosalinity records from the southeast of South Australia (Gouramanis et al., 2010) and the semi-arid Wimmera region (Kemp et al., 2012) confirm significant centennial-scale Holocene hydrologic variability for southeastern Australia.

The rapid changes in water level, ostracod valve chemistry, and lamination formation seen in Lake Keilambete and Lake Gnotuk during the Holocene indicate that their sediment records are sensitive palaeoclimatic archives which have recorded rapid and frequent variations in environmental conditions. Lake level reaches a Holocene maximum at 7.2 ± 0.2 ka, contemporaneous with a precipitation maximum recorded in northern Tasmania (Xia et al., 2001). Lake levels drop towards modern levels from about 5.0 ka onwards, which coincides with an abrupt increase in sea-ice expansion in the Southern Ocean (Hodell et al., 2001), a sharp drop in δ18O in Taylor Dome (Steig et al., 2000), and as a decline in discharge from the Murray-Darling River (Gingele et al., 2007).

sec.title: Regional setting
sec.p: The two studied lakes occur in the western district of Victoria, in southeastern Australia (Figure 1). Modern-day climate affecting the lakes is temperate, with hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters. Precipitation has varied dramatically over the last 50 years from 600 to 1000 mm/yr. The annual balance between P/E strongly influences lake water levels and water salinity, with the historical lake decline caused by a shift in P/E from 0.96–0.94 to about 0.79 (Jones et al., 2001). Kirono et al. (2009) estimate that for Lake Keilambete, the P/E ratio decreased even further to 0.69 for the 10 years from 1998 to 2008.

caption.p: Map of southern Australia showing the location of Lake Keilambete and Lake Gnotuk relative to other sites discussed in the text.

sec.p: Lake Keilambete is a flat-bottomed maar crater lake, as first described by Bowler (1970). At the time of coring, it was a relatively shallow (~9 m) lake with prominent old shorelines circling the lake at various heights below the crater rim and a salinity of ~ 102 g/l. As an isolated crater with a lake surface area of 2.7 km2 and a catchment of 4.2 km2, lake level is primarily controlled by the P/E ratio, but also receives a small component of groundwater inflow from the Port Campbell Limestone aquifer (estimated at ~10% compared with rainfall) (Jones et al., 1998). Analysis of boron isotopes in the lake further confirms that groundwater is a relatively minor contributor to the lake hydrology (Vengosh et al., 1991). Accelerator Mass Spectrometry 14C dating of the groundwater discharging into Lake Keilambete showed a reservoir age of almost 2000 years (Wilkins et al., 2012).

Lake Gnotuk is a flat bottomed maar crater lake located only 18 km east of Lake Keilambete, and has been shown to have very similar water chemistry, ecology, and sediment properties (Barton and Barbetti, 1982; De Deckker, 1982; Dodson, 1974a; Timms, 1976). At the time of coring, it was a ~ 17 m deep lake with a surface area of 2.2 km2 and a catchment of 7.2 km2. The maar crater is a closed catchment, although at high lake levels, water flows into the lake from the adjacent Lake Bullenmerri (Figure 2). Lake Gnotuk also displays past shorelines around the crater wall, but not as prominently as at Lake Keilambete. Salinity is currently ~ 80 g/l, and has been increasing since 1841, at which time Lake Bullenmerri overflowed into Gnotuk (Currey, 1970). The earliest reliable estimate of the maximum lake depth was 35 m in 1903, resulting in a lake-level decline of 16.5 m in 73 years (23 m/century) (Gregory, 1903 in Timms, 1976). Between 1841 and 1966, adjacent Lake Bullenmerri receded at the same rate (23 m/century).

caption.p: Map of Lake Bullenmerri/Lake Gnotuk complex, showing bathymetry, location of overflow (stars) (Timms, 1976), and topography in metres above sea level (BMR, 1977). The circles on the shoreline of Lake Gnotuk show the position of now emerged trees, dating to 1.72 ± 0.16 ka (black circle) and 8.58 ± 0.21 ka (grey circle) (see Wilkins et al., 2012). A bathymetric map of Lake Keilambete is presented in Jones et al. (2001).

sec.p: The lake waters in Keilambete and Gnotuk are inhabited by nektic ostracods, whose calcitic valve remains have been used to reconstruct physico-chemical conditions in the lakes through time (Chivas et al., 1985, 1993; De Deckker, 1982; Gouramanis, 2009) and salinity levels based on an ostracod transfer function (Gouramanis, 2009).

sec.title: Past research
sec.p: Bowler (1970, 1981) characterised surface sediment texture in Lake Keilambete from a series of cores at varying depths, and used the data, along with a short sediment core and qualitative inferences from carbonate mineralogy and the presence of ooids, to reconstruct a Holocene water-level curve.

A combination of historical records and modelling has shown that recent decreases in P/E have resulted in lake water levels declining by ~20 m in the past 167 years (Keilambete) and by ~17 m in the past 125 years (Gnotuk) (Jones et al., 2001; Kirono et al., 2009). Jones et al. (2001) confirmed that the water-level decline was climatically driven. That both lakes responded to known changes in the P/E ratio over the period covered by instrumental rainfall records has been demonstrated via modelling (Jones et al., 2001). On the basis of the similarities in basin morphology, sediment accumulation rates and magnetic resonance, it has also been suggested that water level in Lake Gnotuk responded similarly to Lake Keilambete over the Holocene (Barton and Barbetti, 1982; Barton and Polach, 1980).

Dodson (1974a) identified the Lake Keilambete freshwater phase (based upon the presence of the alga Pediastrum) as occurring somewhat later in the Holocene, between about 7.3 and 5.6 ka, with the most saline phase around 3.6 ka, although his dating was not as extensive as Bowler’s. Dodson (1974b) observed conditions which led to the precipitation of aragonite in association with the alga Enteromorpha nana in Lake Gnotuk. From this, Dodson (1974a) postulated that algal growth/blooms in the open water of Lake Keilambete engenders change in lake water CaCO3 saturation levels, precipitating aragonite which is then deposited as fine laminae in the lake sediment. We suggest that aragonite laminae in the Lake Gnotuk core were formed in a similar manner.

De Deckker (1982) inferred Holocene salinity changes in Lake Keilambete based on microscopic fossil remains, principally of ostracods, and also showed similar results for Lake Gnotuk. Chivas et al. (1985) applied Sr/Ca ratios of ostracod carapaces to derive a palaeo-salinity curve for Lake Keilambete. Their curve, based on 34 analysed intervals, is similar in trend and magnitude to Bowler’s lake-level curve, although it is notable that the majority of the salinity excursions occurred 400 to 800 years prior to lake-level changes reconstructed by Bowler (1981), despite using the same chronology. Furthermore, Chivas et al. (1985) detected four salinity peaks (and associated troughs) in the mid to late Holocene, whereas Bowler’s (1981) smoothed curve only shows three. On the basis of a shift from aragonite to dolomite deposition, and the Sr/Ca results, Chivas et al. (1985) postulated that salinity increased rapidly from ~ 30 to 90 g/l around 4.7 ka, with the consequent inference that there was a dramatic decrease in the P/E ratio at this time.

In a more recent work, Chivas et al. (1993) re-measured Sr/Ca on Lake Keilambete ostracods, along with new measurements of ostracod δ18O and δ13C on the same ostracod valves. They interpreted that there was not a clear relationship between Bowler’s (1981) reconstructed past lake levels (developed from sediment texture and Sr/Ca data) and the δ18O and δ13C, which they attributed to the confounding effects of the early Holocene, low lake-level brine chemistry affecting the ostracod valve trace element chemistry.

The reliability of Lake Keilambete as a ‘lacustrine pluviometer’ was re-assessed by Jones et al. (2001), who suggested that at higher lake levels, Lake Keilambete was influenced by a perched water-table associated with a nearby swamp. Consequently, at high water levels, the lake level does not respond to changes in P/E in a linear manner, making the lake less suitable as a palaeo-rain gauge at these times. Because Lake Gnotuk is higher in the landscape, it is not affected by a local water-table, making it a potentially better indicator of P/E during wetter climate phases (Jones et al., 2001). Nevertheless, caution is still required, as adjacent Lake Bullenmerri can overflow into Lake Gnotuk during periods of very high lake levels.

sec.title: Coring and core sampling
sec.p: A Mackereth corer with a 4 m long PVC core barrel was used to recover two sediment cores each from Lake Gnotuk and Lake Keilambete (Mackereth, 1958; Neale and Walker, 1996). Supplementary short cores (< 1 m length) were taken from both lakes with a percussion corer (e.g. Parker and McCann, 1988). The boat used as the coring platform was re-positioned by approximately 50 m before taking each core. Further information on laboratory procedures is provided in Wilkins et al. (2012). Details of the studied cores are provided in Table 1.

caption.p: Details of core locations, water depth, core length, and sedimentary characteristics of the Mackereth cores discussed in the text.

sec.title: Particle size analysis
sec.p: The use of sediment particle size as a lake depth proxy requires a site-specific knowledge of the relationship between sediment texture and lake depth, and the relative errors involved with calculating the latter. Bowler (1970) measured the proportion of coarse-grained material (> 40 µm) from the modern sediment–water interface at various depths in Lake Keilambete. He also measured the > 40 µm fraction from a recent sediment core, and correlated this with lake-levels over the historic period. Timms (1976) measured the particle size from the sediment–water interface and a range of lake depths for Lake Gnotuk, but did not construct a lake-depth proxy record. This study applies the same method as Bowler (1970), but uses the >63 µm sediment fraction as a proxy of lake depth, on smaller, more frequently spaced intervals in order to construct a higher resolution record of past water depth for both lakes. Equations were fitted to the sediment texture/lake depth measurements of Bowler (1970) and Timms (1976), along with measurements made on modern shoreline sediments and on a lake-full end member (Figure 3a and b).

caption.p: Relationship between sediment texture (% >63 μm) and lake depth for (a) Lake Keilambete, and (b) Lake Gnotuk. The lake-full measurement (hollow star) is defined as the finest particle size measurement from the Holocene sediment core, assumed to be equal to the crater overflow depth of 40 and 73 m, respectively. For Lake Gnotuk, a modern shoreline sediment sample (hollow square) was used as an analogue for the wave disturbed zone (~ 2 m depth).

sec.p: Samples representing 1 cm of core sedimentation (7–8 cm3 of sediment) were removed at 3–4 cm intervals down-core, and disaggregated in 10% v/v hydrogen peroxide for 3–5 weeks. Samples were wet sieved, with the < 63 µm fraction captured in 1 l settling flasks. The > 63µm fraction was oven dried at 100°C overnight and weighed. The < 63 µm fraction was left to settle in 1 l containers for 24–72 h, the clear supernatant was aspirated off, and the resultant fine sediment fraction was oven dried at 100°C overnight and weighed to calculate the proportion of material >63 µm. Measurements were made on 94 samples for Lake Keilambete and 78 samples for Lake Gnotuk. Owing to irregular spacing of sample intervals and varying sedimentation rates, sampling frequency varies from every 20 to 260 years in Lake Keilambete and 30 to 450 years in Lake Gnotuk.

sec.title: Dating
sec.p: Fourteen Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS) 14C dates and 14 quartz Optically Stimulated Luminescence (OSL) dates were obtained from a 3.89 m sediment core from Lake Keilambete (core Keil02), and 15 AMS 14C and 16 OSL dates from a 3.75 m sediment core from Lake Gnotuk (core Gn01). Supplementary AMS 14C dating of lake and spring water at Keilambete showed that 14C depleted water (a reservoir age of 1940 ± 30 yr) affected the 14C activity of Keilambete lake water (Wilkins et al., 2012).

OSL dates measured on single-grains and very small aliquots of sand-sized quartz recovered from the sediment cores, indicate the presence of a radiocarbon reservoir in Lake Keilambete consistent with that measured on modern ostracods, and demonstrate that there is no 14C reservoir in Lake Gnotuk during the Holocene. Most of the AMS 14C dating was conducted on ostracods and foraminifera, in an effort to answer whether large observed age differences (past bulk carbonate dates of Bowler (1970, 1981) overestimated their coeval organic dates by between 1700 and 2800 calendar years) was primarily due to a lake-water 14C reservoir, or to the incorporation of reworked carbonates.

A systematic offset between the 14C and optical ages in Lake Keilambete justifies the use of a lacustrine reservoir correction, although the optical dating was insufficiently precise to define changes in the reservoir magnitude with time. Discussion around the treatment of reservoir ages dating and age models used for the lake-level reconstructions presented here are available in Wilkins et al. (2012). One sigma age errors on calibrated 14C dates are typically ± 200 years for Lake Gnotuk, and ± 400 years for Lake Keilambete (owing to uncertainty from the lake radiocarbon reservoir). OSL dates show good agreement with the radiocarbon dates; one sigma age errors vary from 70 to 2000 years (Wilkins et al., 2012).

sec.title: Core characterisation and laminae counting
sec.p: Archive cores from Lake Gnotuk (Gn02) and from Lake Keilambete (Keil01) were analysed in 100 cm lengths for bulk density (gamma-ray attenuation), magnetic susceptibility, and P-wave velocity at Geoscience Australia, using a Geotek™ Multi Sensor Core Logger (MSCL).

The number of laminae in each core was manually counted directly from digital photographs of the wet sediment cores in Photoshop 7.0. Pixel width in the digital images was approximately 5 µm (230 pixels/cm). Distinctive laminae sequences were used to cross-correlate the studied and archived cores (Wilkins, 2009).

sec.title: Ostracod valve chemistry
sec.p: Ostracod valves were extracted from 1 cm thick sediment slices obtained at ~ 2 cm intervals from the sediment cores, and seven species were recognised from the Lake Keilambete core (Australocypris robusta, Diacypris compacta, D. dietzi, Reticypris herbsti, R. clava, Platycypris baueri and Mytilocypris praenuncia), and three species (A. robusta, D. compacta and R. herbsti) from the Lake Gnotuk core (Supplementary Figures 1 and 2, available online).

Ostracod valves from these subsamples were subsequently prepared for chemical analysis (Sr/Ca, Mg/Ca, Na/Ca, Ba/Ca, δ18O and δ13C) following the procedures outlined in Gouramanis et al. (2010). Only horizons containing sufficient quantities of well preserved adult valves were analyzed for trace metals or stable isotopes. For Lake Keilambete, 79 trace metal and 89 stable isotope analyses were obtained, and for Lake Gnotuk, 69 trace elemental and 75 isotopic analyses. Only Sr/Cawater results, reconstructed using the partition coefficients of Gouramanis and De Deckker (2010), are discussed in this paper.

In each horizon examined for ostracod stable isotopes, between one and ten valves of the same species, after microscopic evaluation of the cleanliness and integrity of the valves, were selected to fulfil the 80 to 120 µg weight requirement of the Finnigan MAT251 mass spectrometer. It is assumed that these multivalve isotopic analyses capture the intrasample variability and reflect the mean isotopic composition of the valves within the interval.

The trace metal composition of four species of ostracods, Australocypris robusta, Mytilocypris praenuncia, Diacypris compacta and Reticypris herbsti was determined from the Lake Keilambete fossil assemblages. Three ostracod species (A. robusta, M. praenuncia and D. compacta) and one foraminifer species (Ammonia beccarii) were also analyzed for their stable isotope composition.
A. robusta, D. compacta and R. herbsti were analyzed for trace metal composition and stable isotopes, and A. beccarii was analyzed for stable isotopes from the Lake Gnotuk cores.

sec.title: Ostracod salinity transfer function
sec.p: A salinity reconstruction from the fossil ostracod assemblages in each core was possible using the known salinity ranges of each of the species collected from inland athalassic lakes from southeastern Australia. A training data set of 491 salinity measurements and associated ostracod species (five outliers were removed from the overall training data set) were collected from Tasmanian and mainland southeastern Australian lakes (Gouramanis, 2009). The Modern Analogue Technique (MAT) was used to reconstruct salinity, as total dissolved solids (TDS) in g/l using the C2 program (Juggins, 2003). The MAT utilised the presence/absence of ostracod species and the weighted average of ten modern analogues, the Bray-Curtis percent dissimilarity coefficient and 4999 Bootstrap crossvalidation iterations (Gouramanis, 2009).

sec.title: Dating
sec.p: A detailed discussion of the dating and age models for the sediment cores from Keilambete (Keil02) and Gnotuk (Gn01) is presented in Wilkins et al. (2012). A comparison of the radiocarbon and quartz optical dating indicated that Lake Keilambete is prone to a lacustrine reservoir of approximately 670 ± 175 years, which has been accounted for in the age model. There was no evidence of a lacustrine radiocarbon reservoir in Lake Gnotuk. Core Keil02 contains a continuous record of sedimentation from approximately the present day back to 9.5 ka. Core Gn01 contains a continuous record of sedimentation between 0.7 and 10.0 ka, with a potential hiatus and/or mixing affecting some of the sediment deposited prior to this. A radiocarbon date near the base of core Gn01 returned an age of 11.5 ± 0.3 ka.

sec.title: Lake Keilambete
sec.p: Three main sedimentary facies were observed in core Keil02. From 0 to 180 cm consists of laminated green, grey and brown mud with sand-sized ostracods and quartz grains. The boundary at 180 cm marks the transition between the ‘upper’ and ‘lower’ Keilambete muds identified by Bowler (1970) and De Deckker (1982). The lower 40 cm of core Keil02 contains the ‘grey clays’ identified by Bowler (1970), which consists of laminated green, grey and brown mud with sand-sized ostracods and quartz grains and abundant carbonate laminae. Comparison of two readily identifiable carbonate laminae sequences 21 cm apart near the top of core Keil02 and previously published core records show excellent correlation (± 1 cm) to cores KF (Barton, 1978) and KG (Bowler, 1970 and De Deckker, 1982).

Laminae counts, water content, carbonate content and loss on ignition for core Keil02 are presented in Supplementary Table 1 (available online), and density and magnetic susceptibility measurements for Core Keil01 are presented in Supplementary Table 5 (available online).

sec.title: Lake Gnotuk
sec.p: The upper part of core Gn01 consists of finely laminated sediments, which vary in colour from black to green-brown. There are notable occurrences of pink and buff coloured carbonate-rich sediments in the core between 68 and 80 cm. The lower part of the core (293 to 389 cm) consists of coarsely laminated to unlaminated grey sediments with gradational colour changes, with the exception of the section between 316 and 354 cm, which consists of unlaminated, porous grey sediment with abundant brown mottling. Observation of the coarse particle size fraction (> 63 µm) of the sediment from this part of the core showed abundant concentrations of well rounded carbonate ooids as well as reworked gastropods between 316 and 354 cm.

Correlation between Mackereth cores Gn01 and Gn02, using identifiable laminae as stratigraphic tie-points and correcting for gaps in the core-liner shows a relationship of the form y = 1.027x +22, with a correlation coefficient of 0.999, indicating that the sediment cores are nearly identical, with no stretching or compression, but that Gn01 has not representatively sampled the upper 22 cm of the lake sediment, as sampled by Gn02. Consequently, there is a gap in the reconstructed lake-level record and laminae counts (performed on core Gn01 only). One ostracod sample was recovered and analyzed from the top 1 cm of core Gn02, but ostracods were otherwise rare or absent in the upper 22 cm of core Gn02. Laminae counts, water content, carbonate content and loss on ignition for core Gn01 are presented in Supplementary Table 2, and density and magnetic susceptibility measurements for Core Gn02 are presented in Supplementary Table 6 (supplementary tables available online).

sec.title: Lake-level reconstruction using sediment particle size
sec.p: It is immediately apparent from the unsmoothed data (Figures 4 and 5) that past lake levels, as determined from changes in sediment particle size, fluctuate rapidly (see also Supplementary Tables 1 and 2, available online). This is supported by historic observations, which demonstrate that lake level can drop at a rate of 23 m per century (Jones et al., 2001). Given an average sampling interval of 3 to 4 cm between particle-size measurements, lake-level changes of >40 m between two data points (approximately 120 years) could thus be expected without invoking changes in P/E greater than that observed following European settlement.

caption.p: Records from Lake Keilambete showing: (a) modelled lake-level reconstructed from the >63 μm sediment fraction from core Keil02 (black diamonds). The thick shaded line is a 3 point smooth incorporating a 2 m curve-fitting error (see Figure 3). At the top of the graph, hollow diamonds indicate the mean age of quartz OSL dates, and hollow circles indicate the mean age of AMS 14C dates (see Wilkins et al., 2012). The hollow star shows the age of a relict tree in growth position on the 10 m shoreline (Bowler, 1970). Vertical grey bars show periods of lake filling, and are continued through the other plots to aid correlation; (b) hollow histograms show the core lamination counts presented as number of laminae per 100 years. Small dark vertical bars show the number of carbonate laminae per cm; (c) Sr/Ca of lake water reconstructed from ostracod valves; (d) δ18O measured on valves of D. compacta (open squares), A. robusta (open circles), M. praenuncia (open diamonds) and A. beccarii (crosses); (e) reconstructed salinity (Total Dissolved Solids in g/l) using the Modern Analogue Technique (MAT) on ostracods (Gouramanis, 2009).

Records from Lake Gnotuk showing (a) modelled lake level from the >63 μm sediment fraction from core Gn01. Symbols are as for Figure 4, with hollow stars indicating the age of relict tree trunks exposed at the 18 m shoreline (GX-0149, equivalent to 1.72 ± 0.16 ka, obtained by ED Gill from a (then) submerged tree from Lake Gnotuk, and ANUA36015, dated to 8.58 ± 0.21 ka (see Wilkins et al., 2012). Vertical grey bars show periods of lake-level filling, and are continued through the other plots to aid correlation. The period between 11 and 10 ka is shown in light grey, because of uncertainty with the dating in this section of the core; (b) core lamination counts presented as number of laminae per 100 years. Small dark vertical bars show the number of carbonate laminae per cm; (c) Sr/Ca of lake water reconstructed from ostracod valves; (d) δ18O measured on D. compacta (open squares), A. robusta (open circles) and R. herbsti valves (crosses).

sec.p: It must be noted that at deeper lake levels, the relationship between lake depth and sediment particle size is very sensitive to relatively small variations in the proportion of sand-sized material. For instance, in Lake Gnotuk, 50 m and 70 m lake depths are equivalent to 97.0% and 99.5% of sediment <63 µm, respectively. Stochastic variation in the influx of storm transported or wind-blown coarse particles (e.g. clastic grains, vegetation, insect chitin, gastropods) can potentially result in significant variations in the percentage of coarse material. Given this, isolated variations in the shape of the lake level curve should not be overinterpreted.

Encouragingly, the finest textured sediment assumed to be representative of crater-full depth, occurs at 238 cm in core Gn01 (99.5% <63 µm), and 296 cm in core Keil02 (99.9% <63 µm). An AMS 14C date from charcoal fragments at 295 cm in core Keil02 dates to 7.33 ± 0.18 ka, and the age models place peak lake level at 7.23 ka in Lake Keilambete and 7.17 ka in Lake Gnotuk, synchronous considering the dating errors of several hundred years (Wilkins et al., 2012).

sec.title: Ostracod fauna and salinity
sec.p: The ostracod assemblages and timing of changes in faunal associations are available in the supplementary section (available online). The diagnostics for the MAT-modelled TDS show good agreement between modelled and expected values (Root Mean Square Error = 0.3 and R2 = 0.85; Gouramanis, 2009). The results of the salinity reconstruction for Lake Keilambete is presented in Figure 4, but is not shown for Lake Gnotuk as it provides little further explanatory power because only three species are present, all of which have very similar (but broad) salinity tolerances. Where no ostracods are preserved in the core, the salinity could not be reconstructed.

sec.title: Lake Keilambete (TDS)
sec.p: Between ~ 9.5 and 8.0 ka, salinity fluctuates between 46 and 71 g/l, before decreasing to the no-analogue value. The TDS record recommences at 4.7 ka. From 4.7 to 4.1 ka, salinity ranges from 22 to 71 g/l. Salinity remains higher (58 to 71 g/l) between 3.9 and 2.8 ka, with fresher excursions (22 g/l) centred on ~ 3.3 and 3.1 ka. Between 2.6 and 1.9 ka, reconstructed salinity is comparatively low (22 g/l), with only one high salinity value at 2.3 ka. Between ~ 1.9 and 1.2 ka, the MAT calculates consistent TDS values of between 61 and 71 g/l. No ostracods are present between 1.2 and 0.6 ka. Less saline values (22 g/l) occur at 0.5 and 0.4–0.2 ka, with a more saline excursion (58 g/l) around 0.45 ka. The last ~150 years of the record shows an increasing salinity trend (from 10 to 75 g/l).

sec.title: Lake Keilambete
sec.p: Between 8.0 and 5.0 ka and 1.2 to 0.6 ka, no ostracods are present in Lake Keilambete. Trace metals were analyzed between 9.7 and 8.2 and 4.0 to 1.2 ka. Stable isotopes on the ostracod valves were analyzed between 9.2 and 8.1 ka, 4.9 to 1.2 ka, and from 0.2 ka to the core top.

Sr/Cawater reconstructions are on average higher after 3.8 ka (0.0395±0.015) than prior to 8.2 ka (0.023±0.01), and range from 0.008 to 0.08. δ18O is always positive and records a higher degree of variability before 8.2 ka, but with a lower mean (2.32 ± 0.85‰) than after 4.8 ka (3.23 ± 0.79‰). δ13C is relatively depleted prior to 8.7 ka (−2.75 to 1.64‰) and enriched after this period ranging from 0.35 to 8.12‰.

sec.title: Lake Gnotuk
sec.p: Between 7.6 and 3.6 ka and from 1.0 ka to 1 cm from the core top (core Gn01), no ostracods were preserved in Lake Gnotuk sediments, preventing analysis of valve chemistry. Trace metals were analyzed from 11.4 to 7.6 ka, 3.6 to 2.0 ka, 1.4 to 1.0 ka, and in the upper centimetre of core Gn02 (near modern age). Stable isotopes were analyzed from 11.4 to 7.6 ka, 3.7 to 1.0 ka and in the upper centimetre of core Gn02.

As with Lake Keilambete, the δ18O of Lake Gnotuk ostracods is always relatively enriched, ranging from −1.2 to 4.86‰. The mean values prior to 7.6 ka (2.26 ± 0.71‰) and post 3.6 ka (3.15 ± 0.69‰) are very similar to those of Lake Keilambete during these periods. The δ13C record of Lake Gnotuk ranges from −8.26 to +3.91‰, becoming relatively enriched after 8.0 ka. Prior to 8.0 ka, mean δ13C was −2.52 ± 2.58‰ and after 3.6 ka was 0.98 ± 0.79‰.

sec.title: Lake-level reconstructions
sec.p: The timing of the reconstructed high and low lake-level phases from Lake Gnotuk matches well with those reconstructed from Lake Keilambete, given the dating errors associated with the age models and the difference in sampling intervals between the two lake records (Figure 6). Lake Gnotuk has higher amplitude changes in lake level than Lake Keilambete, which may be partially explained by the modulating effect of the perched water-table in Lake Keilambete, as proposed by Jones et al. (2001). During wet phases, flow of water over the sill from Lake Bullenmerri would also act to boost levels in Lake Gnotuk. This paper demonstrates that both Keilambete and Gnotuk show a clear lake-level maximum at 7.2 ± 0.2 ka (weighted mean age). The time of maximum lake depth matches the phase of most effective precipitation (7.4–7.0 ka) reconstructed from a northern Tasmanian speleothem (Xia et al., 2001) (Figure 6d).

caption.p: (a) Smoothed (three point) lake level reconstructed from modelled lake depths in Lake Keilambete and Lake Gnotuk relative to 1970 lake levels (10 m in Lake Keilambete, 18 m in Lake Gnotuk). Closed circles indicate the modelled lake depths for Lake Keilambete, and open squares indicate the same for Lake Gnotuk. Hollow stars indicate the age of exposed tree trunks near the modern shoreline. Vertical grey bars denote periods of apparent lake filling (Precipitation>Evaporation), and are continued through the plot to aid correlation; (b) ten-point smooth of δD from the EPICA Dome-C ice core (Stenni et al., 2001); (c) illite (closed circles) as a percentage of clay material measured in Murray Canyons core MD03-2611 by (Gingele et al., 2007). The illite record shows a period of high discharge from the Murray River between 9.5 and 7.0 ka, followed by a decreasing trend until 2.0 ka, matched by an increase in 87Sr/86Sr (open circles) showing increased aridity inferred from the presence of aeolian clays. The letters MM and dashed line show the proportion of illite in the clays at the modern Murray River mouth; (d) growth rate (in μm per year) measured in the Lynds Cave stalagmite from northern Tasmania (Xia et al., 2001).

sec.p: The observed increase in effective precipitation could be associated with increased sea-surface evaporation due to high sea-surface temperatures (peaking at 7.5 ± 0.1 ka) observed in Murray Canyons core MD03-2611, which is located in a precipitation source area 500 km to the west of the crater lakes (Calvo et al., 2007). Moros et al. (2009) also identified a cold phase around 7.3 ka in the adjacent Murray Canyon core (MD03-2607) that was preceded by a phase of strong westerlies between 10 and 7 ka. The timing of the subsequent decline in lake levels is consistent with the proposed re-organisation of the southern westerlies which has been observed in New Zealand (Shulmeister, 1999), South America (Lamy et al., 2001), and Antarctica (Hodell et al., 2001).

Lake levels drop towards modern levels in Lake Gnotuk and Lake Keilambete from about 5.0 ka onwards, which is accompanied by a sharp increase in the rate of carbonate deposition, and an increase in laminae formation in Lake Keilambete. This period of change coincides with the end of the ‘hypsithermal’, visible as an abrupt increase in sea-ice expansion in the Southern Ocean (Hodell et al., 2001), as a sharp drop in Deuterium in Taylor Dome (Steig et al., 2000), the commencement of sea surface cooling in the Murray Canyons region (Calvo et al., 2007), and increased variability in other southeastern Australian lacustrine records, such as Blue Lake, South Australia (Gouramanis et al., 2010) and Blue Lake, New South Wales (Stanley and De Deckker, 2002).

The ostracod data, although discontinuous because of the absence of ostracods from large sections of the sediment cores (particularly when lake levels were high and the lake would have been undersaturated with respect to calcite and aragonite), confirm the overall trends in lake level recognised by the grain size reconstruction.

Although in general, the Sr/Ca of ostracod valves is not directly related to water salinity, Chivas et al. (1985) showed that this was the case for Lake Keilambete, which is extremely alkaline and therefore buffered despite the numerous carbonate microlaminae deposited on the lake floor. For more information, refer to Gouramanis (2009).

sec.title: >11.5–10.9 ka
sec.p: Lake Gnotuk fills to 15–35 m depth, salinity is high (from remnant saline crust on dry lake floor), few to no laminations. No sediment was recovered from Lake Keilambete for this period in our core.

sec.title: ~10.9–8.9 ka
sec.p: Reconstructed lake levels drop to ~ 10 m in Lake Gnotuk. Dating is ambiguous for Lake Gnotuk around 10.9 to 10.0 ka, owing to possible bioturbation and/or sediment mixing by wave action in the shallow lake. Modelled salinity (MAT TDS) oscillates from ~ 30 to 70 g/l in Lake Gnotuk. The Lake Keilambete record begins around 9.5 ka, with modelled salinity increasing from ~50 to 70 g/l around 9.3 ka, with the Sr/Cawater values from this period being affected by brine chemistry (e.g. Chivas et al., 1985). Deposition of carbonate laminae in Keilambete during this period may indicate warmer conditions (e.g. Dodson, 1974a).

sec.title: ~8.9–8.2 ka
sec.p: Reconstructed lake depths in Lake Keilambete increase sharply after 8.9 ka, indicating an excess of precipitation over evaporation. There is a short but prominent drop in water level at Lake Keilambete around 8.4 to 8.1 ka, lasting approximately 300 years. The lake depth reconstruction from Lake Gnotuk, which is of low resolution at this time, shows a more gradual increase in lake levels after 8.8 ka. A sample of wood from a tree in growth position at the 18 m shoreline in Lake Gnotuk dates to this phase (8.6 ± 0.3 ka), consistent with the error envelope on the modelled lake level curve (Figure 4).

sec.title: ~8.2–7.1 ka
sec.p: Both lakes undergo a synchronous, millennial-long period of lake filling between ~ 8.2 and 7.1 ka. Lake Keilambete shows a steady increase in lake depth, but Lake Gnotuk records a sharp drop followed by a subsequent increase in water depth around 7.7 ka. Both lakes reach their maximum depth at the same time (mean age = 7.2 ± 0.2 ka). The lake-level maxima coincide with an effective precipitation maximum between 7.4 and 7.0 ka recorded in a Tasmanian speleothem (Xia et al., 2001), which implies that the regional Holocene P/E maximum was briefer than previously thought from the old Lake Keilambete lake-level reconstruction (Bowler and Hamada, 1971). Ostracods are not preserved in the sediment from 8.1 ka onwards in Lake Keilambete and 7.6 ka onwards in Lake Gnotuk, consistent with higher lake levels resulting in calcium carbonate undersaturation.

sec.title: ~ 7.1–5.2 ka
sec.p: The particle size reconstruction indicates that lake levels are higher than modern, but there is a progressive trend of declining water levels in both lakes. Very few to no laminations occur in the Lake Keilambete sediments. The continued absence of preserved ostracods in both sediment records indicates that lake waters remain undersaturated in calcite.

sec.title: ~ 5.2–4.0 ka
sec.p: The particle size reconstruction indicates a further decline in lake levels in both lakes. This coincides with a rapid increase in carbonate deposition in both lakes and increase in laminae formation in Lake Keilambete. Ostracods are once more preserved in the sediments, indicating that the lake water is no longer undersaturated in calcite. Ostracod shell chemistry in Lake Keilambete (from 5.0 ka onwards) confirms a period of increased evaporation.

sec.title: ~4.0–2.1 ka
sec.p: Lake levels are on average, slightly higher than modern in both Gnotuk and Keilambete. This period in Lake Keilambete was previously identified as having fluctuating salinity by Bowler (1970, 1981) and Chivas et al. (1985, 1993). The Keilambete lake-level reconstruction shows four minima equivalent to modern level (around 3.9, 3.5, 2.8 and 2.3 ka), with the intervening maxima around 20 m height. Lake Gnotuk shows three more protracted lake-level minima at ~3.6, 3.2 and 2.1 ka. A small increase in lake level in Lake Gnotuk around 3.2 ka corresponds to a less enriched δ18O signal and decrease in the Sr/Ca of the lake water.

sec.title: ~2.1–1.2 ka
sec.p: The particle size reconstructions show that Keilambete and Gnotuk reach a late-Holocene lake-level minimum during this phase. The minimum is not synchronous (~1.8 ka in Keilambete and ~ 1.3 ka in Gnotuk). In Keilambete, the Sr/Cawater shows saline conditions peaking at 1.9 and 1.6 ka, with the 1.9 ka phase more saline (0.067 compared with 0.040). This is consistent with the Keilambete MAT TDS, which shows a substantial saline phase from 1.9 to 1.2 ka. The exposed shoreline trees at Keilambete date to this low lake-level period (1.78 ± 0.27 ka) (Bowler, 1970). The Sr/Cawater in Lake Keilambete shows a decreasing trend from 1.6 to 1.2 ka, at which point ostracods are no longer preserved in the sediment. The Gnotuk ostracod valve δ18O indicates drier conditions during this phase.

sec.title: ~1.2–0.8 ka
sec.p: The particle size reconstruction indicates a rapid increase in lake depth in Lake Gnotuk, although not quite as high as the 7.4 ka peak, which may be accentuated by water inflow from Lake Bullenmerri. Lake Keilambete shows a slower rise in water depth. There is a sharp increase in laminae deposition in both lakes (peaking around 1.0 ka), including the deposition of aragonite laminae, possibly indicating a period of warm, wet conditions. In Lake Gnotuk, the Sr/Cawater and δ18O provide independent confirmation of lake water freshening. Ostracods are not preserved in the Lake Keilambete sediment during this phase.

sec.title: ~0.8–0.1 ka
sec.p: At Lake Keilambete, the particle size and TDS reconstructions indicate a short period of lake-level decline around 0.5 ka, followed by a rise in lake levels and drop in salinity peaking at 0.3 and 0.2 ka, respectively. The Lake Gnotuk depth reconstruction does not cover this period because of the upper part of Gn01 undersampling and potentially mixing the top of the sediment profile.

sec.title: ad 1841–present (Historic period)
sec.p: Settlers records indicate high lake levels in both lakes at the start of the phase, with consistent decline since 1841 (Currey, 1970). Ostracod shell chemistry from the uppermost two samples in the Keilambete core indicates increasing salinity, congruent with falling lake levels. There is an ostracod chemistry data point from the top centimetre of core Gn02 (an undated core), which is believed to be of modern age on the basis of stratigraphy and faunal associations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The technique of using sediment grain size to model past lake depth in the maar craters of Lake Gnotuk and Lake Keilambete demonstrates a robust agreement in lake levels and P/E trends during the Holocene. The Lake Keilambete reconstruction presented here more than doubles the sampling density of previous studies (Bowler, 1981; Chivas et al., 1985) and, importantly, has now been validated by reference to Lake Gnotuk. For those times when ostracods were preserved in the lake sediment, the use of valve Sr/Ca ratios and the ostracod MAT TDS as a supplementary technique provides an independent check on lake level (salinity being inversely proportional to lake depth owing to the closed nature of the basin). Whilst the differing sensitivities of the two methods cause disagreement in the magnitude of lake-level shifts, they generally agree well when it comes to the timing of the initiation and speed of those changes.

Rapid changes in lake level, ostracod valve chemistry, and lamination formation indicate that Lake Keilambete and Gnotuk records are sensitive palaeoclimatic archives that reflect rapid and frequent variations in environmental conditions during the Holocene. It has been demonstrated elsewhere that lake levels in Keilambete and Gnotuk have been shown to reflect the regional P/E ratio (Jones et al., 2001). Interestingly, similarities in the pattern and timing of these lake-level changes presented here to ice core δ18O (EPICA Dome C, Antarctica) may indicate a strong temperature component to the P/E ratio, which could potentially be resolved to provide a continuous Holocene precipitation record for southeastern Australia.

Reconstructed lake levels in Keilambete and Gnotuk record a maximum at 7.2 ± 0.2 ka which is contemporaneous with the precipitation maximum recorded in a speleothem in northern Tasmania (Xia et al., 2001), and a cooling of sea-surface temperatures offshore South Australia (Moros et al., 2009). Lake levels drop towards modern levels from about 5.0 ka onwards, which coincides with the end of the ‘hypsithermal’, visible as an abrupt increase in sea-ice expansion in the Southern Ocean (Hodell et al., 2001), as a sharp drop in δ18O in Taylor Dome (Steig et al., 2000), and as a decline in discharge from the Murray-Darling River (Gingele et al., 2007). Persistent recurrent periods of lower water levels in Keilambete and Gnotuk in the mid to late Holocene (between 4.0 and 1.2 ka) indicate multicentennial periods of less effective rainfall, which should be a cautionary lesson for contemporary land managers in southern Australia, especially in the context of observed recent warming and rainfall decline (CSIRO, 2012; Kirono et al., 2012).

ack.p: The primary author acknowledges the assistance of Judith Shelley with picking ostracods for AMS radiocarbon dating; Steve Tims for running the accelerator; Kenneth McMillian for general OSL laboratory assistance, Tim Pietsch for OSL reader time, Stewart Fallon for preparing and running the Keilambete lake water 14C samples, Chris Leslie for high-resolution gamma spectrometry measurements, Peter Harris and Tony Watson (Geoscience Australia) for the use of the Geotek MSCL, Lynda McMorrow and Joe Cali for ostracod valve analysis, and John Dodson, Sharron Glasgow, and especially Jim Neale for assistance with the Mackereth coring.
